data.title: Graham, Durbin Push for Bipartisan Dream Act
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham and Democratic Sen. Dick Durbin joined a gathering of more than 100 'Dreamers' at the U.S. Capitol to push for the senators' bipartisan legislation to protect DACA recipients. 
"I've never seen more bipartisan support for the idea than than right this moment. The American people have heard you. They share your dream and overwhelmingly support your dream," said Graham.
"What you represent are people who can bring real value to America make it a better place, " Durbin said. "Lindsey is right in saying that we are poised to do the right thing as a nation and you are going to be the reason," he said.
Several "Dreamers" also spoke at the event.
"The Dream Act is not controversial. The American public is on our side," said Maria Praeli, who came to the U.S. from Peru when she was five years old."
President Donald Trump announced last month he was ending the DACA program and giving Congress six months to come up with a fix. 
The president has suggested he could revisit the issue if Congress doesn't come up with a solution in time, but administration officials testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee Tuesday said that immigrants' temporary work permits would begin to expire absent congressional action, and they would become subject to deportation.
Wednesday's event took place as senators convened their first hearing on the topic since Trump announced he was winding down DACA, which Republicans have long denounced as an unconstitutional overreach by President Barack Obama.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/4c78c10e24af784c763f76a7313b0141 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Trump Hails Vegas Police, Firefighters As Heroes
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) President Donald Trump met with police, firefighters and cab drivers who ferried those wounded in the Las Vegas shooting to hospitals and congratulated them on their professionalism and hailed them as heroes. 
Trump called the suspect a "sick, demented man.'' 
Sheriff Joseph Lombardo of the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department pointed to two young women in the room and identified them as dispatchers who were amazing. He said there would be a third female dispatcher in the room but she decided to go to a beach in Mexico. 
"She needed a break, and a margarita,'' one of her fellow dispatchers said.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/e76c73eb08faec67a8709fc221dd44d5 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Trump: We Are With Vegas '100%'
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) U.S. President Donald Trump met privately with victims of the shooting at a Las Vegas hospital Wednesday.
"It makes you proud to be an American," Trump told reporters.
He said the nation was with Las Vegas 100 percent and said now was not the time to talk about gun control measures.
As he walked away, Trump said he had confidence in Secretary of State Rex Tillerson.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/0860d2258b9c9aade68818298ea1cfe9 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Nobel Chemistry Winner: It’s Very ‘Humbling’
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) Three researchers based in the U.S., U.K. and Switzerland won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry on Wednesday for developments in electron microscopy. 
One of the winners, Joachim Frank developed a method to generate three-dimensional images of the molecules of life.
Frank said the method, called cryo-electron microscopy, meant medicine no longer focuses on organs but looks at the processes in the cell.
Frank, who teaches at New York's Columbia University, shares the 9-million-kronor ($1.1 million) prize with Jacques Dubochet of the University of Lausanne and Richard Henderson of MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology in Cambridge, Britain.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/d40def690724842734168b27e9eb05d8 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Trump: 'America is Truly a Nation in Mourning'
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) President Donald Trump is telling the people of Las Vegas that the nation stands with them to help bear the pain of the worst gun massacre in modern U.S. history.
He says at the city's Metropolitan Police headquarters that, "Our souls are stricken with grief for every American who lost" someone in Sunday night's shooting. He added, "We will struggle through it together."
At least 59 people died and 527 were injured when a gunman on the 32nd floor of a hotel on the Vegas Strip opened fire on an outdoor country music festival.
Trump says, "We stand together to help you carry your pain."
His remarks came during a daylong visit with victims, families and first responders.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/9eecd92943e33ef86d767d74bb7d3ec8 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Texas Shop Sold Guns to Vegas Shooter
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) Paul Peddle was watching television Sunday night when he saw news of the Las Vegas shooting. Something clicked for Peddle, who owns B & S Guns in Garland, Texas, when he heard shooter Stephen Paddock once lived in Mesquite, Texas, just a few miles from his shop.
Peddle said he came in Monday, and searched Paddock's name in the sales system. 
He said Paddock had purchased pistols and a revolver on several occasions in 2010 and 2011. 
Peddle said Paddock came into the shop with his girlfriend Marilou Danley in 2016, but did not buy anything on that visit.
"He never purchased any long guns here, nothing that would have been used in the attack," Peddle said.
"If you had to meet him the last time he was in here in 2016, you would never have an assumption that he was anything other than a very cordial extremely nice person," he said. "He had his handgun license. He had everything. All the criteria was taken care of. So there was no immediate red flag up."
As he spoke, customers came in and out of the store. Peddle and his staff remembered all of them regardless of how long ago they had been in to shop. He asked one woman about her daughter's wedding and how the catering had gone. Peddle's bulldogs wander the store freely. Woody, his 11-month-old puppy greeted every customer Wednesday.
"We know everyone who comes in. It's just the kind of store we are. When we saw the photo of his girlfriend, we definitely remembered her," Peddle said. "She sat on the floor for more than an hour and a half playing with my dogs. She loved them. I sent her photos of her playing with them to her phone."
Peddle said Paddock asked questions during that 2016 visit, but did not make any purchases. 
He said he asked about "Trigger pulls" and modifications he could make to his guns. Peddle said trigger pulls are used to lighten the spring on triggers.
He said the couple were very kind to each other, noting that Danley was walking with a "tricked out" cane with bedazzling on it because of a surgery. Peddle remembered Paddock walking her to the car and helping her get up.
"He was very charismatic with her, very sweet. That's the word I would use," he said. "I didn't sense any tension. She couldn't really care at all about the guns. We could have been selling furniture and she wouldn't have cared. She was just in love with our puppies."
Peddle said the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms came to get his sales records Tuesday. 
He said he didn't have the surveillance footage from 2016 because ATF had previously collected that footage for its investigation into the July 7 Dallas sniper attack.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/3da8817c159dde5627653d644bb13f46 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Pro-Spain demonstration in Barcelona
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) A day after strongly attended pro independence gatherings two hundred Spanish loyalists decided to gather in central Barcelona and show their opposition to the independence process. 
The crowd marched and chanted, disrupting traffic on Avinguda Diagonal while waving Spanish flags.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/66f561fb699cd72a8324f9c0cc52aa6b 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Trump Lands in Washington Following Vegas Visit
data.description:
(5 Oct 2017) President Donald Trump and First Lady Melania landed in Washington following a somber Wednesday spent at hospital bedsides and at a vital police base in stricken Las Vegas. 
Trump offered prayers and condolences to the victims of Sunday night's shooting massacre during his daylong trip. He also thanked the nation's first responders and doctors who rushed to save lives. 
"America is truly a nation in mourning," he said, before adding that many families "tonight will go to bed in a world that is suddenly empty." 
It was a somber address from a provocateur president who prides himself on commanding strength but sometimes has struggled to project empathy at times of tragedy.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/4cc04935b9579d7df9af20a013851b5b 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Nerves rattled, Puerto Rico elderly anxious after hurricane
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) Locked out of his home and with nowhere else to go, Wilfredo Ortiz Marrero rode out Hurricane Maria inside a Jeep, which was lifted off its wheels by floodwaters in the parking lot. 
He then endured days without enough food or running water. 
The lights are back on Wednesday at his residence for low-income elderly people, and food has started arriving, but he still waits as long as he can each night to leave the company of others in the lobby. 
Alone in his room, he sometimes starts to shake. 
The hurricane that pummeled Puerto Rico two weeks ago and the scarcity-marked aftermath are taking a toll on islanders' equilibrium. 
The U.S. territory's government counted two suicides among the death toll that has increased to 34, and with many communities still waiting for power and clean water, there is concern about others reaching a breaking point. 
Students and staff at Ponce Health Sciences University are visiting shelters and people in hardest-hit communities to provide psychological help, among other services.
Officials count the death toll now at 34 from 16 on the basis of a report commissioned by Governor Ricardo Rossello, to consult with hospitals and gain a more complete picture. 
The count also includes sick and elderly who died after the storm, including some who died because oxygen could not be delivered amid power outages.
Ortiz and other residents of the residential tower in Trujillo Alta, outside San Juan, say the building administration ordered them to leave ahead of the hurricane. 
Some were picked up by family, but Ortiz said with relatives to collect him, he had no choice but to stay in his Jeep until a chain around the building was removed. 
Another resident, Felix Manuel Lopez, a 73-year-old Army veteran, said he has seen a Veterans Affairs counselor to help with anxiety that came back after he returned from a shelter to his darkened apartment.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/f4b7ab67ceab5f16073b07b21fd28935 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Young Immigrants Seek To Renew Deportation Protection
data.description:
(5 Oct 2017) Tens of thousands of young immigrants have reapplied for the programme protecting them from deportation, hoping this renewal won't be the last time they're able to stay in the country they've called home since childhood. 
More than 112,000 renewals for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrival program, or DACA, had been sent to federal government as of Wednesday, according to U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services. 
Thursday was the deadline for the 154,000 recipients eligible to reapply.
The rush of paperwork was prompted by the Trump's Administration's announcement in September that DACA would be phased out in March. 
Until then, the Trump Administration said Congress needed to address the issue of immigrants who were brought to this country by their parents as children. DACA was created by President Barack Obama in 2012 and nearly 700,000 immigrants were under the programme.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/8082a5ee4813f883fe52791ead123ffd 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Vegas Tourists Find Normalcy Amid the Heartbreak
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) THE PARTY, FOR THE MOST PART, IS BACK ON IN SIN CITY.
SOUNDBITE (English) Erica Boaheme, Visiting from Toronto, Canada:
"We're going out. We're turning up tonight but I still feel guilty."
AN EMOTION MANY ARE FEELING AFTER THIS WEEK'S HORRIFIC EVENTS IN LAS VEGAS.
SOUNDBITE (English) Jess Gillis, Visiting from Canada:
"You're happy but you still think about them." 
AT FIRST, THE PEOPLE OF LAS VEGAS REACTED LIKE ANY OTHER TOWN WOULD WHEN CONFRONTED WITH TRAGEDY. 
PENN JILLETTE OF PENN AND TELLER WAS AMONG THE THOUSANDS TO DONATE BLOOD AND PLATELETS IN THE AREA FOLLOWING THE ATTACK.
SOUNDBITE (English) Penn Jillette, Magician:
"I tell jokes, I do tricks and this is well I'm afraid to say quite literally the least I can do."
THE MAGICIANS CANCELLED THEIR SHOW MONDAY NIGHT, BUT JILLETTE SAYS HE THINKS IT'S A GOOD THING VEGAS IS STILL VEGAS.
SOUNDBITE (English) Penn Jillette, Magician:
"Those people that were shot, they didn't want the world to stop. Nobody wants the world to stop when there's a tragedy."
LAS VEGAS IS A CITY BUILT ON ADULT FUN, WHERE ON ANY GIVEN DAY, SEVERAL HUNDRED THOUSAND VISITORS ARE OUT LOOKING FOR A GOOD TIME. 
SOUNDBITE (English) Penelope Alvarez, Visiting from Corona, Calif.:
"We've been planning this for several months now. Why would we change our plans?"
WHILE SOME ARE FINDING IT HARD TO ENJOY THEIR TRIP...
SOUNDBITE (English) Claudia Keller, Visiting from Basel Switzerland:
"After such a tragedy, you don't deserve to party like this you know? I was not in the mood to party."
OTHERS SAY THE GUILT ISN'T BOTHERING THEM
SOUNDBITE (English) Penelope Alvarez, Visiting from Corona, Calif.:
"Not really, not enough to stop me from having fun."
DESPITE THE INCREASED POLICE PRESENCE AND VARIOUS HOTEL MARQUEES ASKING FOR PRAYERS FOR THE VICTIMS AND THANKS TO FIRST RESPONDERS, 
Denmark
"I'm sad for the loss of lives, for the family members but life goes on."
LITTLE SEEMS AMISS ON THE LAS VEGAS STRIP.
KRYSTA FAURIA, ASSOCIATED PRESS, LAS VEGAS


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/ac17f77b8f7d77414be0eadfc2aa5021 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

SOUNDBITE (English) Penn Jillette, Magician:
"Those people that were shot, they didn't want the world to stop. Nobody wants the world to stop when there's a tragedy."
LAS VEGAS IS A CITY BUILT ON ADULT FUN, WHERE ON ANY GIVEN DAY, SEVERAL HUNDRED THOUSAND VISITORS ARE OUT LOOKING FOR A GOOD TIME. 
SOUNDBITE (English) Penelope Alvarez, Visiting from Corona, Calif.:
"We've been planning this for several months now. Why would we change our plans?"
WHILE SOME ARE FINDING IT HARD TO ENJOY THEIR TRIP...
SOUNDBITE (English) Claudia Keller, Visiting from Basel Switzerland:
"After such a tragedy, you don't deserve to party like this you know? I was not in the mood to party."
OTHERS SAY THE GUILT ISN'T BOTHERING THEM
SOUNDBITE (English) Penelope Alvarez, Visiting from Corona, Calif.:
"Not really, not enough to stop me from having fun."
DESPITE THE INCREASED POLICE PRESENCE AND VARIOUS HOTEL MARQUEES ASKING FOR PRAYERS FOR THE VICTIMS AND THANKS TO FIRST RESPONDERS, 
Denmark
"I'm sad for the loss of lives, for the family members but life goes on."
LITTLE SEEMS AMISS ON THE LAS VEGAS STRIP.
KRYSTA FAURIA, ASSOCIATED PRESS, LAS VEGAS


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/ac17f77b8f7d77414be0eadfc2aa5021 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
asset.author: AP Archive

data.title: Raw: Trump Returns to WH Following Vegas Visit
data.description:
(5 Oct 2017) President Donald Trump and First Lady Melania landed in Washington following a somber Wednesday spent at hospital bedsides and at a vital police base in stricken Las Vegas. 
Trump offered prayers and condolences to the victims of Sunday night's shooting massacre during his daylong trip. He also thanked the nation's first responders and doctors who rushed to save lives. 
"America is truly a nation in mourning," he said, before adding that many families "tonight will go to bed in a world that is suddenly empty." 
It was a somber address from a provocateur president who prides himself on commanding strength but sometimes has struggled to project empathy at times of tragedy.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/f4980a3911c60f8e8aa9c0742e3a259a 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Foxconn to Build Huge Plant in Small Wisc. Town
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) Taiwanese technology manufacturer Foxconn will locate its new sprawling manufacturing complex in southeastern Wisconsin.
At a news conference Wednesday, Racine County and other local and economic development officials announced the site of the mammoth manufacturing campus will be in the Village of Mount Pleasant. 
The community with a population of about 26,000 is about 25 miles (40 kilometers) south of Milwaukee and 60 miles (100 kilometers) north of Chicago.
Racine County Executive Jonathan Delagrave calls the plant and its $10 billion investment a turning point for the country. The plant, the largest industrial complex in the state, could eventually employ 13,000 people.
The Wisconsin Legislature approved a $3 billion incentive package for Foxconn, although the state's economic development agency is working on the final contract.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/beadbc5684db45733997f92f99b53378 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: NY Protesters Criticize Trump Puerto Rico Visit
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) Protesters gathered in New York on Wednesday to demonstrate against the federal response to Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico, expressing outrage at comments made by President Donald Trump on Tuesday.
"He say (Trump) that Katrina was worse than Maria because not much people dead. What did he want? Eliminate the Puerto Rican people from the map?," said Glorivee Caban, a Puerto Rico native who spoke at the rally.
During his visit to the island on Tuesday, Trump told local officials "every death is a horror," but that "but if you look at a real catastrophe like Katrina and you look at the tremendous, hundreds of and hundreds and hundreds of people that died, and you look at what happened here with, really, a storm that was just totally overpowering, nobody has ever seen anything like this."
Demonstrators also pushed for the federal government to wipe away the commonwealth's debt, which has caused financial instability on the island.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/f3860ead675b19c961b2b48341f6f2ef 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Trump se reúne con víctimas del tiroteo de Las Vegas
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) RESTRICTION SUMMARY: 
STORYLINE: 
Diciendo que fue un "día muy, muy triste" para él personalmente y para el país, el presidente Donald Trump viajó el miércoles a Las Vegas, donde un atacante mató a 59 personas durante un concierto. 
El mandatario se reunió con supervivientes y autoridades de agencias del orden tras el peor tiroteo masivo en la historia moderna de Estados Unidos. 
El Air Force One aterrizó en el aeropuerto cerca del famoso bulevar de Las Vegas por la mañana. 
El atacante Stephen Craig Paddock mató el domingo al menos a 59 personas e hirió a 527. Algunas de las víctimas sucumbieron por las balas, otras al tratar de escapar en medio del caos. 
Trump estuvo acompañado de la primera dama Melania Trump. 
El martes, al salir de la Casa Blanca hacia Puerto Rico, Trump calificó al atacante de Las Vegas como "demente" e "individuo muy, muy enfermo". También elogió a la policía de Las Vegas, diciendo que ellos habían hecho un "trabajo increíble". 
Cuando se le preguntó sobre leyes sobre armas, el presidente respondió: "Estaremos hablando de leyes sobre armas a medida que pase el tiempo". 
===SOURCE: POOL===
===========================================================

data.title: Trump: 'We Will Endure the Pain Together'
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) President Donald Trump is telling the people of Las Vegas that the nation stands with them to help bear the pain of the worst gun massacre in modern U.S. history.
He said at the city's Metropolitan Police headquarters that "in the months ahead, we will all have to wrestle with the horror of what has unfolded this week."  He added, "We will struggle through it together."
At least 59 people died and 527 were injured when a gunman on the 32nd floor of a hotel on the Vegas Strip opened fire on an outdoor country music festival.
Trump says, "We stand together to help you carry your pain."
His remarks came during a daylong visit with victims, families and first responders.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/04744029e16c9eaf4bbaa35fab7c0d5f 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Appeal for "respect" from Spanish Deputy PM to Puigdemont
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) Spain's Deputy Prime Minister on Wednesday appealed to Catalan President Carles Puigdemont "to respect Spain and to handle its institutions with the respect they deserve." 
Soraya Saenz de Santamaria was responding to a speech by Puigdemont in which he vowed to push ahead with a roadmap for the region's secession.
Santamaria argued that Puigdemont's televised statement late on Wednesday had created more unease and unrest following the disputed independence referendum.
Violence marred Sunday's vote which the Spanish government says was illegal and not valid.
It blames Puigdemont for the violence.
Catalonia's leader has urged the government to accept mediation in the country's deepest political crisis in decades.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/846fb3d6b1017ae70dd6dab250ae32d9 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Graham, Durbin Push for Bipartisan Dream Act
data.description:
(4 Oct 2017) Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham and Democratic Sen. Dick Durbin joined a gathering of more than 100 'Dreamers' at the U.S. Capitol to push for the senators' bipartisan legislation to protect DACA recipients. 
"I've never seen more bipartisan support for the idea than than right this moment. The American people have heard you. They share your dream and overwhelmingly support your dream," said Graham.
"What you represent are people who can bring real value to America make it a better place, " Durbin said. "Lindsey is right in saying that we are poised to do the right thing as a nation and you are going to be the reason," he said.
Several "Dreamers" also spoke at the event.
"The Dream Act is not controversial. The American public is on our side," said Maria Praeli, who came to the U.S. from Peru when she was five years old."
President Donald Trump announced last month he was ending the DACA program and giving Congress six months to come up with a fix. 
The president has suggested he could revisit the issue if Congress doesn't come up with a solution in time, but administration officials testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee Tuesday said that immigrants' temporary work permits would begin to expire absent congressional action, and they would become subject to deportation.
Wednesday's event took place as senators convened their first hearing on the topic since Trump announced he was winding down DACA, which Republicans have long denounced as an unconstitutional overreach by President Barack Obama.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/0749d964ccfdd0263f680e6be16ae503 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
